p: According to Reference [ 32], Artemisia has two basic chromosome numbers, the largely predominating x = 9 and the less extended x = 8, with the ploidy levels ranging from diploid to dodecaploid in the species with x = 9 chromosomes and from diploid to hexaploid in those with x = 8 chromosomes. The chromosome number x = 9 is the most common not only in the genus Artemisia but also in the tribe Anthemideae and the family Asteraceae [ 33]. The evolutionary pathway determining the chromosome number in Artemisia is affected by the successive or simultaneous effects of polyploidy (both autopolyploidy and allopolyploidy) and dysploidy [ 35]. The existence of two basic chromosome numbers indicates that Artemisia is a dysploid genus. Dysploidy is seen in Artemisia, Absinthium, and Dracunculus, which are the three main groups of the genus, while Seriphidium and Tridentatae display only one basic chromosome number, x = 9 [ 32].
